Anatomy and Physiology 
II 
(end 
of Lecture 
6) 
By the end of this lecture, you should be able to: 
o
 
Know the name/function of bee’s internal body parts (ex: Malpighian 
tubules, spermatheca, 
haemolymph
, etc.) 
o
 
Explain how 
honey bees 
“breathe” 
o
 
Contrast their 
haemolymph 
with the vertebrate blood 
o
 
Summarize how 
honey bees process food, from ingestion to excretion 
o
 
Recognize that they have an Immune system, and remarkable cognitive 
abilities that would put your favorite dog or cat to shame 
o
 
Compare and contrast the reproductive system of workers, queens, and 
drones 
o
 
Explain why a beheaded worker bee can still sting you and why drones 
cannot 
o
 
Compare and contrast the reproductive system of workers, queens, and 
drones

brain 
Consists of: 
• 
a brain 
• 
a ventral nerve cord 
running from head to 
end of abdomen 
• 
7 ganglia at various 
junctions throughout 
the body along that 
nerve cord 
Ventral nerve cord 
One of the 
7 ganglia 
Nervous system 
Note
: a 
ganglion
=a structure containing 
a number of 
nerve cell bodies, typically 
linked by synapses, and often forming a swelling on a nerve fiber.

Bees have a “brain” but it barely 
resembles a human brain. 
• 
Function 1 
is to receive sensory information from 
compound eyes, antennae and mouthparts 
• 
Three separate brain regions for this: Optic lobe 
OL, antennal lobe AL, Suboesophageal ganglion 
SEG 
(
no need to remember those compartments) 
Optic lobe OL: visual info
antennal lobe AL: olfactory info
Suboesophageal ganglion SEG: 
info coming
From mouth parts
info processed and transmitted to 
motor centers of ventral nerve cord

• 
Function 2 
is learning and memory 
• 
Mushroom bodies MB are important in a bee's ability to 
learn, remember and act on that sensory information. 
Rely heavily on paired areas of 
brain called mushroom bodies
Large relative to other brain 
regions in honey bees
large mbs also found in other 
social bees ex: bumblebees; but 
not observed in solitary bodies
Mbs can combine info from 
multiple sensory modalities 
(sight, sense, taste)
not many insects can do this

brain 
• 
Most 
locomotion is 
controlled 
by 
the 
ganglia not 
the 
brain
. 
• 
A 
beheaded 
insect 
can 
move 
its legs 
and 
wings 
vigorously
. 
• 
A 
decapitated  bee 
can 
walk 
and 
sting 
(!) 
but 
flying 
is 
not 
possible because 
it is 
out of 
balance 
without 
the 
head
. 
The last 
of 7 ganglia

A s
mall and simple 
brain
, 
but 
still enough 
for 
sophisticated cognitive 
abilities 
Only ~ 1 million neurons 
But enough for: 
-
Fast computing 
-
Understanding conceptual 
relationships 
-
Having 
a 
cognitive 
metric map 
-
Associative learning

Honey bees are capable of Classical conditioning 
(aka Pavlovian conditioning, or associative learning)

w.youtube. 
com

?v
=t1TiBLiL 
_f4 
The Proboscis Extension Reflex (PER) can be used to make workers pair a 
biologically potent stimulus (e.g. sugar solution) with a previously neutral 
stimulus (e.g. volatile odor).

And they 
may 
even be able to do simple 
arithmetic, and to understand the concept of 0

et al.

R
eproductive syste
m 
Queens have ovaries and ovarioles, oviducts, a 
9
 
spermatheca and a vagina (genital chamber) 
Mate in 2nd week of adult life with an avg of 12 
males, then never again; can lay 1500 eggs per day
stores millions of 
sperms gathered 
during those matings 
and keeps them alive 
and viable for years
Mated

Compared to queens, the reproductive 
system of worker bees is underdeveloped 
spermatheca 
ovaries 
Semi
-
sterile 
fertile 
Do not lay eggs in nest under normal conditions

BTW, t
he sting is a modified egg 
laying device (Females only!) 
cross
-
section of the abdomen 
of a female honey bee 
12
 
Honey bees don’t have an oppostior
eggs just fall off at the base of the sting
Males can not sting

No sting! 
Males have testes, and a semen delivering 
system (penis or 
endophallus
) 
13

Mating occurs 25 to 82 feet above ground level in a drone 
aggregation areal! 
Queens mate with 5
-
20 males (Polyandry) 
Drone aggregation area: specific location where 100s of drones from multiple local 
colonies wait for the arrival of virign queens

Endophallus 
is everted, semen is 
propulsed 
inside the female with a pop 
Mated males leave their 
endophallus 
in the 
queen’s abdomen (mating sign) 
Mated male dies, Mated queens return to the 
nest and starts laying eggs within a few days

Beekeepers can perform controlled mating 
semen is collected from a 
then inserted in the reproductive tract 
mature drone that everted its genitalia 
of a virgin queen immobilized in a cage 
using a stereomicroscope and micro
-
manipulated 
syringes and hooks for superb control

Endocrine system 
The endocrine system includes the many glands scattered 
throughout the body that secrete chemicals with 4 main functions 
• 
Wax production 
• 
Communication (internal: hormones; external: pheromones) 
• 
Defense 
• 
Food processing

from Gulen & Cranston 2000 
=> PTTH 
pro
-
thoracico
-
tropic
-
hormone
 
PTTH (storage) 
=> JH  juvenile hormone 
=> Ecdysone  (
ecdysteroids
) 
-
Hormones are of 
three types: 
ecdysteroids 
(ecdysone), 
juvenile hormones, 
and neuropeptides 
-P
roduced by a 
variety of glands 
(no need to remember 
the name and location of 
these glands) 
-T
ransported by 
haemolymph

oney bee
s even have 
an immune system
!

To arm them...

Why evolve to have a barbed stinger? 
What does a wasp have that a vertebrate wants? 
What does a solitary bee have that a vertebrate wants? 
...And what about 
honey
 
bees
?

Why evolve to have a barbed stinger? 
What does a wasp have that a vertebrate wants? 
What does a solitary bee have that a vertebrate wants? 
...And what about 
honey
 
bees
?

HONEY! 
(And larvae!)

Honey badgers, honeyguides, bee eaters, 
and bears 
– 
oh my!

Honey badgers, honeyguides, bee eaters, 
and bears 
– 
and apes!
Honeyguides will even team up with humans to raid bee nests

Venom isn’t the worst part of honey bee biochemical warfare: 
Alarm pheromone 
When bees smell it, their response is: 
• 
Investigation 
• 
A higher likelihood to sting 
Common in nature 
• 
One animal makes a decision, and group members follow them 
• 
The initiator might have better info, or have spent more energy 
making the decision to act 
• 
Leads to stampedes, but also gets whole herds away from 
hungry predators 
triggers other bees to area and increases chances of stinging

A random fluke of evolution: 
don’t eat a banana while you’re opening hives!

Isoamyl acetate 
This is why I made my wife do the dishes for two months!

So 
what happens when a bee stings you? 
Effects of bee venom on the body 
Localized pain 
Itching 
Minor swelling 
“Usual” response: 
A typical adult human can survive 10 stings per pound of body weight 
Always 
scrape
 
(don’t 
pinch
) stingers and venom 
glands out of the skin
Bee sting allergies

How common are severe bee sting allergies? 
Not easy to study... 
Not everyone gets stung by bees twice! 
Surveys often conclude ~0.3-
7.5%, 
with “about 3%” being a common consensus

Bee sting allergies 
Histamine 
Antihistamines block action of histamine 
by chemically blocking histamine receptors

Epinephrine auto-
injector as guard 
against anaphylaxis 
How 
does epinephrine stop allergic reactions? 
Epinephrine affects the same cells histamine does, 
but in opposite directions and more strongly

Why 
does epinephrine stop allergic reactions? 
FIGHT or FLIGHT 
Epinephrine in vertebrates can be thought of as a 
hormone that tells your body: 
“We don’t have time to worry about that right now!” 
Roughly, it turns down body systems responsible for 
“resting” “digesting” and “healing” and turns up “fight” 
and “flight” systems
